<ce:section-title id="sect0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">Two new Co(II) coordination polymers(CPs), namely [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpe)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(Hbppc)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(bppc)(bpm)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>bppc=biphenyl-2,4,6,3′,5′-pentacarboxylic acid, bpe=1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene, bpm=bis(4-pyridyl)amine), have been obtained and characterized by elemental analysis, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), IR spectra and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a binodal (4,6)-connected <ce:bold>fsc</ce:bold> net with a (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>·8)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) topology, while <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows a binodal (5,7)-connected 3D network based on trinuclear [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)]<ce:sup loc="post">5+</ce:sup> units with unusual (3.4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6)(3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>.7) topology. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements reveals that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows ferromagnetic interactions between the adjacent Co(II) ions, whereas <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a antiferromagnetic system.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Two new Co(II) coordination polymers(CPs), namely [Co2(bpe)2(Hbppc)]
n
 (1) and [Co3(μ3-OH)(bppc)(bpm)(H2O)]·3H2O (2) (H5bppc=biphenyl-2,4,6,3′,5′-pentacarboxylic acid, bpe=1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene, bpm=bis(4-pyridyl)amine), have been obtained and characterized by elemental analysis, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), IR spectra and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). 1 shows a binodal (4,6)-connected fsc net with a (44·610·8)(44·62) topology, while 2 shows a binodal (5,7)-connected 3D network based on trinuclear [Co3(μ3-OH)]5+ units with unusual (3.46.52.6)(32.46.57.65.7) topology. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements reveals that complex 1 shows ferromagnetic interactions between the adjacent Co(II) ions, whereas 2 is a antiferromagnetic system.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0010">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0035" view="all">Two new Co(II) coordination polymers with bi- and trinuclear units have been obtained. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a binodal (4,6)-connected fsc net with a (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>·8)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) topology and antiferromagnetic interactions between the adjacent Co(II) ions, while <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a binodal (5,7)-connected 3D network with unusual (3.4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6)(3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>.7) topology and a ferromagnetic system.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
Two new Co(II) coordination polymers with bi- and trinuclear units have been obtained. 1 shows a binodal (4,6)-connected fsc net with a (44·610·8)(44·62) topology and antiferromagnetic interactions between the adjacent Co(II) ions, while 2 is a binodal (5,7)-connected 3D network with unusual (3.46.52.6)(32.46.57.65.7) topology and a ferromagnetic system.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Two Co(II) coordination polymers with different multimetallic clusters as building units.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">A (4,6)-connected <ce:bold>fsc</ce:bold> net and a (5,7)-connected 3D network.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">A antiferromagnetic coupling for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and A ferromagnetic coupling for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sect0025">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Magnetic materials based on transition metal ions with polynuclear units, such as Co(II) and Mn(II), have received increasing attention, owing to its high spin ground state can be obtained from strong exchange interactions between 3d electrons . Noted that, the development of coordination chemistry, many research efforts have been devoted to novel ways to fabricate, characterize and explore fundamental magnetic phenomena . Coordination polymers (CPs) with polynuclear units based on Co(II) and Mn(II) have fascinating architectures and physical properties with widespread applications, such as catalysis, sorption, magnetism and electrical conductivity . However, the final structures of coordination polymers are hardly controlled because the synthesis processes are influenced by many factors, such as the structural characteristics of the ligands, the coordination nature of metal ions, the solvent preference, the pH value of the solution, the reaction temperature and the metal/ligand ratios . Multicarboxylate ligands, which are widely employed to construct such extended architectures, not only bind several metal centers of specific coordination geometry to form polynuclear units but also can transmit the magnetic interaction . Biphenyl-2,4,6,3′,5′-pentacarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>bppc) is an important family of multidentate O-donor, which can be used as the mediators between the metal centers, because multicarboxylate groups have various coordination modes, which allowing interesting structures with higher dimensionality. As well known, the multicarboxylate linkers have been extensively employed as the organic ligands to construct CPs .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Two Co(II) coordination polymers with different multimetallic clusters as building units.
A (4,6)-connected fsc net and a (5,7)-connected 3D network.
A antiferromagnetic coupling for 1 and A ferromagnetic coupling for 2.
Introduction
Magnetic materials based on transition metal ions with polynuclear units, such as Co(II) and Mn(II), have received increasing attention, owing to its high spin ground state can be obtained from strong exchange interactions between 3d electrons . Noted that, the development of coordination chemistry, many research efforts have been devoted to novel ways to fabricate, characterize and explore fundamental magnetic phenomena . Coordination polymers (CPs) with polynuclear units based on Co(II) and Mn(II) have fascinating architectures and physical properties with widespread applications, such as catalysis, sorption, magnetism and electrical conductivity . However, the final structures of coordination polymers are hardly controlled because the synthesis processes are influenced by many factors, such as the structural characteristics of the ligands, the coordination nature of metal ions, the solvent preference, the pH value of the solution, the reaction temperature and the metal/ligand ratios . Multicarboxylate ligands, which are widely employed to construct such extended architectures, not only bind several metal centers of specific coordination geometry to form polynuclear units but also can transmit the magnetic interaction . Biphenyl-2,4,6,3′,5′-pentacarboxylic acid (H5bppc) is an important family of multidentate O-donor, which can be used as the mediators between the metal centers, because multicarboxylate groups have various coordination modes, which allowing interesting structures with higher dimensionality. As well known, the multicarboxylate linkers have been extensively employed as the organic ligands to construct CPs .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">In order to obtain Co-CPs with novel structures and functional properties, an useful strategy is introduced auxiliary N-donor ligands . Using such tactics, our groups have reported some new Co(II)-cluster based mixed-ligand CPs with magnetism, gas adsorption and photocatalysis . As part of our ongoing interest in understanding the ability of the multicarboxylate to direct the assembly of Co(II)-organic systems, herein, in this paper, H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>bppc with five carboxyl groups and different auxiliary N-donor spacers, 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene (bpe) with –CHCH– linker or bis(4-pyridyl)amine (bpm) with –NH– linker, are employed to induce Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>-core aggregation and to tune the structures of polymetallic Co(II)-clusters, resulting in two coordination polymers containing bi- and tri-nuclear units, [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpe)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(Hbppc)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(bppc)(bpm)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). Moreover, their magnetic properties were also investigated and discussed.</ce:para>

As part of our ongoing interest in understanding the ability of the multicarboxylate to direct the assembly of Co(II)-organic systems, herein, in this paper, H5bppc with five carboxyl groups and different auxiliary N-donor spacers, 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene (bpe) with –CHCH– linker or bis(4-pyridyl)amine (bpm) with –NH– linker, are employed to induce CoII-core aggregation and to tune the structures of polymetallic Co(II)-clusters, resulting in two coordination polymers containing bi- and tri-nuclear units, [Co2(bpe)2(Hbppc)]

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0030">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0035">Materials and physical measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">All solvents and reagents were available and were used as received. Elemental analysis for C, H and N was performed on a Flash 2000 organic elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C microanalyzer heated from 25 to 900<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in nitrogen atmosphere. Infrared spectra (4000–600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) were recorded on a FT-IR Nexus spectrophotometer spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were taken on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, <ce:italic>λ=</ce:italic>1.5406<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), with a scan speed of 5°/min and a step size of 0.02° in 2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>. Variable-temperature magnetic measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS XL-7 instrument (2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) in the magnetic field of 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>KOe, and the diamagnetic corrections were evaluated by using Pascal's constants.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental
Materials and physical measurements
All solvents and reagents were available and were used as received. Elemental analysis for C, H and N was performed on a Flash 2000 organic elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C microanalyzer heated from 25 to 900°C in nitrogen atmosphere. Infrared spectra (4000–600cm−1) were recorded on a FT-IR Nexus spectrophotometer spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were taken on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ=1.5406Å), with a scan speed of 5°/min and a step size of 0.02° in 2θ. Variable-temperature magnetic measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS XL-7 instrument (2–300K) in the magnetic field of 1KOe, and the diamagnetic corrections were evaluated by using Pascal's constants.

In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 4-carboxylic group of Hbppc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> is protonated and free of coordination. The other four carboxylate groups of Hbppc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand adopt the (κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-(κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-(κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-(κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-μ<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> coordination fashion to bridge three Co1 and three Co2 (b). The Co1 and adjacent Co2 are bridged by two carboxyl groups in <ce:italic>syn, anti</ce:italic> fashion to generate a binuclear [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> unit with the Co···Co distance of 4.10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Then the binuclear units are linked by Hbppc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands to form a 2D layer (c). Such 2D layers are further interlinked by the bpe linkers to form a 3D network (d).</ce:para>

a). Co1 is six-coordinated with a distorted octahedron geometry by four carboxylato-O from three Hbppc4− ligand (O1, O5#2, O6#2, and O10#1) forming the equatorial plane, and two cis N atoms from two bpe (N3 and N4#3). Co2 is five coordinated with a distorted trigonal-bipyramidal coordination environment, in which three O atoms from three Hbppc4− ligands (O2, O4#4, and O9#1) form the equatorial plane and the apical positions are occupied by two N atoms (N1 and N2#3) with N1–Co2–N2 angle of 177.0(2)°. In 1, 4-carboxylic group of Hbppc4− is protonated and free of coordination. The other four carboxylate groups of Hbppc4− ligand adopt the (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-(κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ6 coordination fashion to bridge three Co1 and three Co2 (b). The Co1 and adjacent Co2 are bridged by two carboxyl groups in syn, anti fashion to generate a binuclear [Co2(COO)2]2+ unit with the Co···Co distance of 4.10Å. Then the binuclear units are linked by Hbppc4− ligands to form a 2D layer (c). Such 2D layers are further interlinked by the bpe linkers to form a 3D network (d).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Analysis of the network topology of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveals that binuclear [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> unit acts as a 6-connected node to connect six other binuclear units. And the Hbppc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand serves as the 4-connected nodes to join four binuclear units. Thus, the 3D structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is designated as a binodal (4,6)-connected <ce:bold>fsc</ce:bold> net with a (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>·8)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) topology (e).</ce:para>

Thus, the 3D structure of 1 is designated as a binodal (4,6)-connected fsc net with a (44·610·8)(44·62) topology (e).

Thus, an unprecedented (5,7)-connected bi-nodal network with the Schläfli symbol of (3·4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·6)(3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·5<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>·7) (f).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Analysis of the network topology of 2 reveals that each trinuclear [Co3(μ3-OH)]5+ unit acts as a 7-connected node to connect five bppc5− and two [Co3(μ
3-OH)]5+ units via two bpm spacers. And bppc5− serves as 5-connected node to connect five [Co3(μ
3-OH)]5+ units. Thus, an unprecedented (5,7)-connected bi-nodal network with the Schläfli symbol of (3·46·52·6)(32·46·57·65·7) (f).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">When the N-donor co-ligand isn't introduced the reaction system, [Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>][H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O]·3[Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bppc)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) is obtained . <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is a 5-connected 3D <ce:bold>acs</ce:bold>−4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> net constructed from [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> dimer units and biphenyl-pentacarboxylate ligand with open hydrophilic channels, uniquely, the [Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> as guest cations coexist in the channels. In <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, The five carboxylate groups of bppc<ce:sup loc="post">5−</ce:sup> ligand display (κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)-(κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-(κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-(κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-(κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-μ<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> binding fashion to link eight Co(II) atoms. When bpe was employed as ancillary ligand, a (4,6)-connected <ce:bold>fsc</ce:bold> net with binuclear [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> unit <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is formed. While bpe was replaced by bpm, a (5,7)-connected net with [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)]<ce:sup loc="post">5+</ce:sup> trinuclear units <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is obtained. In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 4-carboxylic group of Hbppc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> is protonated and free of coordination. The Hbppc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand adopt the (κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-(κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-(κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-(κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-μ<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> coordination fashion, while in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the bppc<ce:sup loc="post">5−</ce:sup> ligand display (κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-(κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-(κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-(κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-(κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-μ<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf> binding fashion.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
When the N-donor co-ligand isn't introduced the reaction system, [Co(H2O)6][H3O]·3[Co2(bppc)(H2O)2]·0.5H2O (3) is obtained . 3 is a 5-connected 3D acs−44·66 net constructed from [Co2(O2C)5(H2O)2]− dimer units and biphenyl-pentacarboxylate ligand with open hydrophilic channels, uniquely, the [Co(H2O)6]2+ and H3O+ as guest cations coexist in the channels. In 3, The five carboxylate groups of bppc5− ligand display (κ1-κ2)-(κ1-κ1)-(κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ8 binding fashion to link eight Co(II) atoms. When bpe was employed as ancillary ligand, a (4,6)-connected fsc net with binuclear [Co2(COO)2]2+ unit 1 is formed. While bpe was replaced by bpm, a (5,7)-connected net with [Co3(μ
3-OH)]5+ trinuclear units 2 is obtained. In 1, 4-carboxylic group of Hbppc4− is protonated and free of coordination. The Hbppc4− ligand adopt the (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-(κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ6 coordination fashion, while in 2, the bppc5− ligand display (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-(κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ9 binding fashion.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0060">PXRD and thermal properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">To confirm the phase purity of the bulk materials, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) has been carried out. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns are in good agreement with each other, indicating that both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> phase purity of the as-synthesized products ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and thermal properties
To confirm the phase purity of the bulk materials, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) has been carried out. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns are in good agreement with each other, indicating that both 1 and 2 phase purity of the as-synthesized products ().

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The TGA curves of the two compounds are shown in . For complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the first weight lost of 9.5% was observed from 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 270<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C corresponding to the lost of coordination water molecules (calcd. 8.7%). Then pyrolysis of the sample occurred from 330 to ~580<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Its mass remnant of 18.4% corresponding to CoO (17.6% calcd). For complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, in the temperature range of 55–165<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the weight loss of free and coordinated molecules is observed at 10.00% (calcd. 8.9%). Then a sharp weight-loss step was observed between 355–500<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, representing the structure collapse.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The TGA curves of the two compounds are shown in . For complex 1, the first weight lost of 9.5% was observed from 100°C to 270°C corresponding to the lost of coordination water molecules (calcd. 8.7%). Then pyrolysis of the sample occurred from 330 to ~580°C. Its mass remnant of 18.4% corresponding to CoO (17.6% calcd). For complex 2, in the temperature range of 55–165°C, the weight loss of free and coordinated molecules is observed at 10.00% (calcd. 8.9%). Then a sharp weight-loss step was observed between 355–500°C, representing the structure collapse.

Among the superexchange pathways between the nearest neighboring CoII ions, the large Co–O–Co angle and the syn–syn bridging mode of the carboxylate group are indication of antiferromagnetic interactions . In 2, the antiferromagnetic interactions are found between CoII ions in the trinuclear units relying on the effect of μ3-hydroxyl group (Co–O–Co 111.74, 112.30, 119.22°) exchange pathway and syn-syn carboxylate exchange pathways. The magnetic susceptibilities data above 20K can be well fitted to the Curie-Weiss law with θ=−69.84K and C=9.55cm3
Kmol−1 for 2, revealing weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the adjacent Co(II) ions.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0070">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">In summary, two Co(II)-MOFs with bi- or tri-nuclear Secondary building units bridging by carboxylates have been prepared. The results reveal that the coordination frameworks can be well modulated by the different coordination modes of the carboxylic groups of multicarboxylate ligands with different degree of deprotonation and nature of N-donor auxiliary ligands. Magnetic studies indicate that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows weak ferromagnetic interactions, while <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits weak antiferromagnetic interactions. The results demonstrate that such pentacarboxylic acid may be used as a versatile building block to construct novel coordination polymers with fascinating structures and properties, also, further synthesis, structures and properties studies of coordination frameworks with Co(II) based mixed-ligand coordination frameworks are under way in our lab.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion
In summary, two Co(II)-MOFs with bi- or tri-nuclear Secondary building units bridging by carboxylates have been prepared. The results reveal that the coordination frameworks can be well modulated by the different coordination modes of the carboxylic groups of multicarboxylate ligands with different degree of deprotonation and nature of N-donor auxiliary ligands. Magnetic studies indicate that 1 shows weak ferromagnetic interactions, while 2 exhibits weak antiferromagnetic interactions. The results demonstrate that such pentacarboxylic acid may be used as a versatile building block to construct novel coordination polymers with fascinating structures and properties, also, further synthesis, structures and properties studies of coordination frameworks with Co(II) based mixed-ligand coordination frameworks are under way in our lab.
